title: 105_hr1478
content: Charitable contributions of computer equipment and software to schools and organizations aiding individuals with disabilities. Special rule for contributions of computer equipment and software used for educational purposes, limiting reduction for qualified educational contributions to the amount determined under paragraph (3)(B). Qualified educational contribution defined as charitable contribution by a corporation of computer software or equipment to educational institutions. The contribution is made to an educational organization, a governmental unit, or a 501(c)(3) organization with expertise in providing training for information technology services and devices at the community level. The contribution is made to provide technology services and devices to individuals with disabilities, their families, and advocates within the United States for educational purposes. The contribution is made to provide technology services and devices to individuals with disabilities for educational purposes, ensuring that the property is not transferred for money or other services. The corporation must provide a written statement ensuring that the property will be used in accordance with specific provisions. Donations to charity for refurbishing computer equipment can be treated as qualified education contributions. The organization must provide a written statement confirming that the property will meet the needs of the recipient and comply with specific requirements. The organization must be a qualified organization under section 501(c)(3) and exempt from taxation. The organization must be a qualified 501(c)(3) organization and engage in computer repair and refurbishment for donation to eligible recipients. Special rules apply for construction and refurbishment of property by the taxpayer. The taxpayer's refurbishment of property is treated as construction. Definitions for computer equipment, software, educational purpose, and disability are provided. The term 'disability' is defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. 'Information technology' includes computer equipment, software, and related services. 'Corporation' is defined as per paragraph (4)(D). Section 170 of the Code is amended to include a new subsection on computer training. For tax purposes, a charitable contribution by a corporation can include qualified computer training. This training involves teaching individuals how to use computer software or equipment donated by the corporation for specific purposes. The subsection (e) of section 170 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for the contribution of digital augmentative speech devices for individuals with disabilities. The taxpayer must receive a written statement from the donee confirming that the training is not in exchange for money, property, or services. A maximum of 8 hours of training per contribution is allowed, and the valuation of the training time is based on the individual's usual wage rate. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for contributions of digital augmentative speech devices to be treated as charitable contributions, with a limit on reduction and qualified training in device use considered a charitable contribution. An entity must be described to receive such contributions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for contributions of digital augmentative speech devices to be treated as charitable contributions for entities described in section 501(c)(3) or governmental units with expertise in providing training for individuals with disabilities. Qualified training refers to training in the use of digital augmentative speech devices. The taxpayer can contribute a digital augmentative speech device to an entity described in section 501(c)(3) or a governmental unit for an individual employed by the entity, receiving training that meets specific requirements. This contribution is treated as a charitable contribution, with limitations on exchanges for money or other benefits. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996, regarding the transfer of property for training purposes. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effectiveness of charitable contributions of computers and software in meeting educational needs of students by December 31, 1998. The report will be submitted to the House Committee on Ways and Means and the Senate Committee on Finance. Additionally, donations to underprivileged schools are addressed. The enhanced charitable deduction aims to encourage donations of computer equipment and software to underprivileged schools serving low-income communities, schools with budgets below the state norm, and schools with low student test scores.
